At 11:59 06/11/2005, you wrote:
>Hi,
>
>Right after I posted my question I realized I had just violated the
>first law when posting in forums/groups: before asking, always search
>back to see if your question has already been answered! I always hate
>it when other people forget to do that. :S Oh well...
>
>Anyway, I did search back immediately after posting and I did find
>your post on "continuous speciation control", but, although your
>method looks promissing, your post did not answer The One Question:
>How well were the individuals spread out over your species? Your
>output shows that the number of species stays around your target of
>30, but it does not show the sizes of these species. Maybe half of
>your population was concentrated in single specie and all other
>species contained only 1 or 2 chromosomes? (That's the result I am
>getting using Stanley's method.) Would that even be a bad thing?

I have this problem a lot and often 50% or more of individuals are in 
the first species.  I think this is just a result of Ken's original 
methodology of trying the species in order when assigning 
individuals, but I forget now whether he said anything about how many 
individuals were in each species.  Note that he did have periodic 
complete re-assignments of all individuals, so that would presumably 
balance things a bit.

I have been considering how to get a more even split, and I two working ideas:

1) move away from presenting the individuals to species in a particular order

2) move away from using similarity to assign species

the ideas behind the second of these are quite complex, and will have 
wait for another day.  For the first, I did already try assigning 
each individual to the closes matching species, rather than the first 
that is close-enough.  But that had the effect of making it hard to 
reduce the number of species when it was too high.  This was because 
all existing species continued to receive some proportion of new 
individuals, however wide the threshold is set.  This makes it hard 
to drive them to extinction.  Two points arise from this:

1a) in the traditional scheme, reduction of species number tends to 
happen by crow-baring all new individuals into the first few species, 
so that the last few go extinct.  This is not what I intuitively 
thought was happening and I'm not sure I like it.
1b) that was before I had continuous species control working, so my 
current scheme might be able to show far more patience when it needs 
to reduce the species count.

The other plan for 1 is to add the individual to the first species 
that matches when the species are presented in a random order.

And the other other plan for 1 is to add the individual to the first 
species that matches and isn't full...

         Ian
